ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course provided a good insight into what it would be like to design a chemical engineering production plant. We learned a lot about the economics of such a plant, and how to size and price the equipment necessary.

I learned some plant economic skills such as interest, payback period, and different kinds of capital needed. In addition, I learned how to operate the Aspen HYSYS simulation and how to estimate and evaluate the production of a new plant.

The course is more focused on real-world engineering topics, like economics, simulation software, and plant safety, which was a nice change from the rest of the ChemE curriculum.  The second half of the course was based on the capstone project, where the instructor guided us along to design a wind-powered ammonia plant.
I developed the ability to seek a multitude of possible solutions to the same problem. Also learned how to use Aspen HYSYS to simulate chemical processes

We learned how to build chemical plants taking into consideration both engineering and economics. We modeled processes in ASPEN HYSYS, did an extensive literature review, and generally got experience analogous to industry work.

This is one of the first courses in the chemical engineering curriculum that goes into the real-world operations of a chemical facility. The first half of the class is devoted to lectures on plant economics, HYSYS simulations, and other useful topics in industry. The second half of the course is for the final project.

I learned a lot about the economy of chemical engineering, like literally macroeconomics kind of stuff. Also, and this will change as the projects change every year, I learned a lot about ammonia production and renewable energy as that was what my project was related to

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: learn about aspects of industry engineering that aren't covered in other courses in the major. 
Weakness: all of the capstone groups in the class are assigned the exact same project, making the capstone project somewhat pointless since we are all reporting the same information in the end.

The strengths of this course is that it allows for you to work in groups on a large long-term project. Also, I enjoyed the aspect of figuring the economic feasibility of our process. I think that weaknesses include that we started the project too late in the semester, and that the first half of the course did not feel like the most useful in the long-run. I think that the economics section of the course should be shortened in order to provide more time for the project. Finally, it seemed like many due dates were unclear, and would be thrown upon us. I think that using the canvas course assignments page would help this drastically.

The strength of the course was the project, as it gave us more practical engineering experience.  The weakness was that, because there was no TA and thus no psets, the first half of the course was almost forgettable.

Dr. Khalil is extremely patient and makes himself available for students as much as he can. Anytime students struggle with material, he offers his precious time and it is a very good opportunity for students to catch up. Weaknesses of this course include the lack of a TA, and the fact that Aspen HYSYS access was only remotely available.

The professor is very good at providing all the resources you need and being helpful when you get stuck. Since we took this class during an online term, it was hard to get enough time to use the lab computers for our process modeling.

The collaboration on the final project is great. I really enjoyed working with my team to make the best project we could. Also the textbook and lecture notes have vast amounts of real-world information on plant economics that are useful for thinking about any business, not just chemicals. Some suggestions for improvement for the course are: 1) longer time to work on the project: I think it would be cool to have more time to do more research on the real-world equipment costs, calling manufacturers etc. and overall improving the simulation as much as possible. In person, it might be worth doing a physical small-scale test/model depending on the type of project. 2) have some student input into the topic of the project. I really enjoyed my project but it  might be interesting to poll the class and see what interests there are, or give an option of topics that students would want to explore more.

I wish there was more time to actually work on the project. So much time was spent on the economics of chemical engineering, and there definitely was enough time to do the project but it was not as satisfying as I feel it could be. It also became a rush at some point.

Although, this class does have a lot of strengths like there is no stress about choosing your own project, I really liked that all the teams worked together on the same project with slight variations between them to compare.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that recording lectures helped with the learning of the material.

The lectures were fine, but the mentoring during the project was difficult.  Prof. Khalil was extremely generous with his time and met with us over the weekend and in the evenings, but it would have been easier if the course was in-person.
Yale should provide students with the Aspen HYSYS software to download onto their devices to facilitate learning. Overall, the rest of the course was very well organized and executed well

I wish there was more use of the canvas website. I feel like canvas has many features implemented to make life easier for students and staff alike and not many features were utilized. The one that comes to mind immediately is the assignments tab, having to email things to your professor, while fine, can feel very wishywashy at times because assignments getting lost in an inbox is too real.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No, never in a million years. We learned very little throughout the semester, received little to no feedback until the week before our final presentation, and the project was not interesting in the slightest.
I would not recommend this course to anyone besides ChemE. It requires a lot of time and effort in an area that really only applies to ChemE.

I would.  I think this course is important for all graduating chemical engineering majors to take in order to recognize the importance of non-scientific, non-mathematical factors in practical engineering.
Definitely recommend, you probably need to take it for your major if you are considering it. Dr Khalil is amazing and is a great teacher and guide throughout the course
You definitely need like all the chemical engineering background to take this course, but if you have that and want to do a huge capstone project then yeah.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There was a mix of live virtual seminars and lectures.
Recorded lectures
Lecture notes
Because this is a final project based class, the last few weeks were kind of a virtual seminar, but mainly it was just a live virtual lecture
